questions: Why does bleaching powder smell strongly of chlorine and does not dissolve completely in water ?
answers: When exposed to air, bleaching powder gives a smell of chlorine. This is because bleaching powder reacts with carbon dioxide from the atmosphere to produce calcium carbonate and chlorine gas.

questions: What is bleaching powder ? How is it prepared? List two uses of bleaching powder.
answers: Bleaching powder is calcium oxychloride. It is prepared by the action of chlorine on dry slaked lime. → CaOCl2 + H2O Ca2 + Cl2  Bleaching power Uses :  Used for bleaching cotton and linen in the textile industry and wood pulp in paper industry etc.  It is used for disinfecting the drinking water. ½+½

questions: What is baking powder ? How does it make the cake soft and spongy ?
answers: Baking Powder is a mixture of sodium hydrogen carbonate and tartaric acid. On heating it liberates CO2 which makes the cake soft and spongy. 1 + 1

questions: How washing soda is prepared from baking soda ?
answers: Recrystallization of sodium carbonate gives washing Soda. It is a basic salt. Na2CO3 + 10H2O → Na2CO3. 10 H2O.

questions: Give two important uses of washing soda and baking Soda.
answers: Uses of Washing Soda :  In glass, Soap and paper industry.  Manufacture of Borax. Uses of Baking Soda :  An ingredient in antacid.  Used in Soda acids, fire extinguishers.

questions: Write the chemical formula of baking soda. How is baking soda prepared ? Write the reaction which takes place when it is heated during cooking.
answers: The chemical formula of baking soda is NaHCO3. ½ It is prepared by using sodium chloride. → NH4Cl + NaCl + H2O + CO2 + NH3  NaHCO3. 1 On heating : 2NaHCO3 Heat → Na2CO3 + H2O + CO2

questions: Name the gas evolved when sodium hydrogen carbonate is made to react with dilute hydrochloric acid. How will you test the gas ?
answers: Carbon dioxide . Pass this gas to lime water, it turns lime water milky.

questions: A white powder is added while baking breads and cakes to make them soft and fluffy. What is the name of the powder ? What are the main ingredients in it ? What are the functions of each ingredient ?
answers: Baking powder. Baking soda and an edible acid like tartaric acid. ½ Baking soda  is used to release CO2 gas when heated. Tartaric acid is used to avoid the bitter taste by reacting with the Na2CO3 formed.

questions: Write the chemical name and formula of gypsum. What happens when gypsum is heated at 373 K. Write chemical equation for the reaction.   ACIDS, BASES AND SALTS
answers: CuSO4 + Fe 

questions: State the chemical name of Plaster of Paris. Write a chemical equation to show the reaction between Plaster of Paris and water.
answers: CaSO4. H2O  When plaster of paris reacts with water, gypsum is formed. → CaSO4·2H2O CaSO4· H2O + 1 H2O  Plaster of Paris Gypsum

questions: Classify the following salts as acidic, basic or neutral :  NaCl  Na2SO4  CaCl2  K2CO3
answers: Acidic salt – CaCl2  Basic salt – K2CO3  Neutral salt – NaCl, Na2SO4

questions: Classify the following salts into acidic, basic and neutral— Potassium sulphate, ammonium chloride, sodium carbonate, sodium chloride.
answers: Neutral Salts : Potassium sulphate, sodium chloride Basic Salts : Sodium carbonate Acidic Salts : Ammonium chloride.

questions: Explain why, an aqueous solution of sodium sulphate is neutral while an aqueous solution of sodium carbonate is basic in nature.
answers: Sodium sulphate when dissolves in water forms strong acid and strong base so its aqueous solution is neutral while sodium carbonate when dissolves in water forms an alkaline solution which turns red litmus blue. It shows that its aqueous solution is basic in nature.

questions: What is the colour of FeSO4.7H2O crystals ? How does this colour change upon heating ? Give balanced chemical equation for the changes.
answers: FeSO4.7H2O is green in colour and loses water of crystallisation when it is heated. It is then decomposed to Fe2O3 , SO2 and SO3. FeSO .7H O → FeSO + 7H O 2FeSO4 ∆ → Fe2O3 + SO2 + SO3

questions: Crystals of a substance changed their colour on heating in a closed vessel but regained after sometime, when they were allowed to cool down.   Name one such substance.  Explain the phenomenon involved.
answers: CuSO4.5H2O CuSO .5H O → CuSO + 5H O    Explanation : On heating, crystal looses water of crystallisation and regain it on cooling.

questions: An aluminium cane is used to store ferrous sulphate solution. It is observed that in few days, holes appeared in the cane. Explain the cause for this observation and write the chemical reaction to support your answer.
answers: Aluminium is more reactive than iron. Aluminium from the walls can react with ferrous sulphate to form its sulphate and iron is precipitated. → Al23 + 3Fe 2FeSO4 + Al 

questions: What would be the colour of the solution when copper oxide and dilute hydrochloric acid are mixed ?  Write a chemical equation which represents that the effect of a base is nullified by an acid and viceversa.
answers: It is blue green. → NaCl + H2O  NaOH + HCl 

questions: How will you prove that a given salt is a carbonate of a metal ?
answers: To salt, add few drops of dilute HCl or H2SO4, if colourless gas is evolved with brisk effervescence and on passing it through lime water, the lime water turns milky, the gas is CO2 and salt is a carbonate of metal.

questions: What is meant by the term hydrated salt ?  Give two examples of hydrated salt which are white and state their chemical formula.
answers: Salt that contains water of crystallisation.  Washing soda — Na2CO3.10H2O Gypsum — CaSO4.2H2O 		Plaster of paris — CaSO4. H2O.

questions: Define water of crystallisation with two examples. How will you prove their existence in the examples given by you ?
answers: Water of crystallisation is a fixed number of water molecules present in one formula unit of a salt. One formula unit of copper sulphate contains five water molecules . The water molecules which form part of the structure of a crystal are called water of crystallisation. Heat CuSO4.5H2O → CuSO4 + 5H2O  copper sulphate)    * Due to loss of water of crystallisation. CuSO4 + 5H2O ¾® CuSO4.5H2O Anhydrous Water Hydrated copper copper sulphate sulphate   * By adding water

questions: A sanitary worker uses a white chemical having strong smell of chlorine gas to disinfect the water tank.  Identify the chemical compound, write its chemical formula.  Give chemical equation for its preparation.  Write its two uses other than disinfection.
answers: Bleaching powder — CaOCl2  Ca2 + Cl2 → CaOCl2 + H2O  Two uses other than disinfection are :  Paper industries  Chemical Industries.  1 + 1 + 1

questions: In one of the industrial processes used for manufacture of sodium hydroxide a gas X is formed as by product. The gas ‘X’ reacts with dry slaked lime to give a compound ‘Y’ which is used as bleaching agent in textile industry.
answers: X = Chlorine gas, Y = Calcium oxychloride → CaOCl2 + H2O  Ca2 + Cl2   lime) oxychloride)  1+1+1

questions: What is meant by water of crystallization ? How many molecules of water are present in hydrated copper sulphate ? Write its formula. What colour change do you observe when it is heated ?
answers: Water of crystallization is the fixed number of water molecules present in one formula unit of salt.  Five molecules of water.  Formula — CuSO4.5H2O  When heated, its colour changes from blue to white.  1

questions: How chloride of lime chemically differs from calcium chloride ?  What happens when chloride of lime reacts with sulphuric acid ? Write chemical equation involved.  Mention two uses of chloride of lime.
answers: Chemically chloride of lime is known as calcium oxychloride. → CaSO4 +  2CaOCl2 + H2SO4  CaCl2 + 2HClO → HCl +  HClO Hypochlorous acid Nascent oxygen Coloured Substance +   → Colourless.   Bleaching powder is used for bleaching purposes in textile and paper industry and in laundry.  It is also used as a disinfectant for water. 1+1+1

questions: A gas X reacts with lime water and forms a compound Y which is used as bleaching agent in the chemical industry. Identify X and Y. Give the chemical equation of the reaction involved.
answers: X is Chlorine Y is CaOCl2  used as bleaching agent. Ca2 + Cl2 → CaOCl2 + H2O

questions: Write the chemical formula of bleaching powder. Write balanced chemical equation involved in the preparation of bleaching powder and write its three uses.  ACIDS, BASES AND SALTS
answers: Chemical formula — CaOCl2 Chemical equation — → CaOCl2 + H2O Ca2 + Cl2  Uses :  For bleaching cotton and linen in textile industry½  As an oxidising agent in a chemical industry.  For disinfecting water.

questions: A white powder is an active ingredient of antacids and is used in preparation of baking powder. Name the compound and explain that how it is manufactured. Give chemical equation.  Write a chemical equation to show the effect of heat on this compound.
answers: Compound is NaHCO3/baking soda/sodium hydrogen carbonate Manufacture - NH3 + NaCl + H2O + CO2 → NH4Cl + NaHCO3 Heat  2 NaHCO3 → Na2CO3 + H2O + CO2  3 Detailed Answer :  The Compound is NaHCO3  Manufacturing Sodium hydrogen carbonate : NH3 + NaCl + H2O + CO2 → NH4Cl+ NaHCO3  On heating, Baking Soda decomposes into Sodium carbonate, water and carbon dioxide. 2NaHCO3 Na2CO3 + H2O + CO2

questions: ‘‘Sodium hydrogen carbonate is a basic salt.’’ Justify the statement. How is it converted into washing soda ? Explain.
answers: It is a salt produced by the neutralization reaction between a strong base  and a weak acid , hence it is a basic salt. It is heated strongly to produce sodium carbonate. 2NaHCO ∆ → Na CO + H O + CO Sodium carbonate is recrystallized to produce washing soda. Na2CO3 + 10H2O  → Na2CO3.10H2O

questions: A student dropped few pieces of marble in dilute hydrochloric acid, contained in a testtube. The evolved gas was then passed through lime water. What change would be observed in lime water ? What will happen if excess of gas is passed through lime water ?
answers: CaCO3 + 2HCl ¾® CaCl2 + H2O + CO2 Marble is calcium carbonate and on reacting with HCl releases CO2. Ca2 + CO2 ¾® CaCO3 + H2O   Lime water turns milky due to the formation of white precipitate of CaCO3. On passing excess CO2, milkiness disappears because Ca2 is formed which is soluble in water. CaCO3 + H2O + CO2 ¾® Ca2 Soluble in water

questions: What happens when a solution of baking soda is heated ? Write chemical equation for the same. Name the product which is responsible for making the bread or cake spongy and fluffy.
answers: When baking soda is heated, it decomposes to produce sodium carbonate, water and CO2 gas. 1 → Na2CO3 + H2O + CO2 2NaHCO3 ∆ CO2 gas produced during the reaction makes the cake or bread spongy and fluffy.

questions: State what happens when :  Gypsum is heated at 373 K.  Blue crystals of copper sulphate are heated.  Excess of carbon dioxide gas is passed through lime water.
answers: It looses water molecules and become calcium sulphate hemihydrate CaSO4. H2O or plaster of paris.  Blue copper sulphate crystals on heating lose water of crystallisation and become white. When these crystals are left open, will absorb moisture from air and regain blue colour.  On passing CO2 gas through lime water, insoluble calcium carbonate is formed. On passing excess of CO2, soluble calcium bicarbonate is formed. → CaCO3 + H2O Ca2 + CO2  Insoluble → Ca2 CaCO3 + CO2 + H2O  Soluble 1+1+1

questions: Write the chemical formula of each of the following :  Plaster of Paris  Gypsum.  How can plaster of paris be converted into gypsum ?   List any one use of plaster of paris.
answers: CaSO4.  CaSO4.2H2O  By mixing with water → CaSO4.2H2O 1 CaSO4. H2O + 1 H2O   For making toys, for supporting fractured bones. 1

questions: A compound ‘x’ on losing partial crystallization of water gives compound ‘y’ which is used for making chalk and other pottery articles. But when ‘x’ is strongly heated, it gives ‘z’ which is used as drying agent. Identify x, y, z and write the chemical equation.
answers: A commonly used compound for making chalks and other pottery articles is plaster of paris. Its chemical formula is CaSO4.½H2O. It is obtained by CaSO4.2H2O on partial losing water of crystallization by controlled heating at 120°-130°C. When CaSO4.2H2O is strongly heated, it loses whole of water of crystallisation and gives anhydrous calcium sulphate. Thus ‘x’ is CaSO4.2H2O; y is CaSO4.½H2O and ‘z’ is CaSO4. Heat CaSO4 .2H 2O 120° → CaSO4 . H 2O + H 2O −130°C   CaSO4 .2H 2O >130°C → CaSO4 . Heat

questions: Mention the products produced when an acid reacts with a base. Give equation of an example of the reaction involved. What is this kind of reaction known as ?
answers: The reaction between an acid and a base that gives a salt and water is known as a neutralisation reaction. Base + Acid ¾® Salt + Water NaOH + HCl ¾® NaCl + H2O

questions: Name the three products of ‘chlor-alkali’ process. Write one commercially or industrially important material each that can be prepared from each of these products.
answers: The three products are : Sodium hydroxide , Chlorine  and Hydrogen . NaOH — for soaps and detergents and paper making or artificial fibers. Cl2 — PVC, pesticides, CFCs. H2 — fuels, margarine, NH3 for fertilizers.

questions: Crystals of a substance changed their colour on heating in a closed test-tube but regained it after sometime when they were allowed to cool down. Name the substance and write its formula and explain the phenomenon involved.   Name the acid and base that would be used to prepare the following salts :  Potassium sulphate 		 Ammonium chloride.
answers: Copper sulphate crystals  5 molecules of water are present in one formula unit of copper sulphate. When heated, its loses its water and salt turns white.  Basic Salt : 		 Base — KOH  Acid — H2SO4   Base — NH4OH  ½ Acid — HCl
